topic.title: RBAC for Administrators and Applications
topic.shortdesc: The Couchbase Role-Based Access Control system allows a full administrator to specify, with fine granularity, the access-rights of other administrators, and of applications; so ensuring that activities are constrained to appropriate areas; in accordance with business-objectives, compliance-requirements, and current expertise.

section.title: Authorization for Full Administrators
section.p: The administrator who initially performs installation and configuration of Couchbase Server is granted full read-write access to the entire system. The user ID of this administrator can be either locally specified, or remotely, by means of LDAP.
Once basic system-configuration has been completed, the initial, full administrator is free to add additional administrators to the system, and specify their levels of access.

section.title: Adding Users
section.p: As full administrator, to add users (each of which might be either an administrator or an application, or both) to Couchbase Server, use the Couchbase Web Console. Access the Dashboard, and left-click on the Security tab, on the vertical navigation-bar, at the left. This brings up the Security view, as follows:

The Security view allows users to be defined, and roles to be allocated to them. It also allows management of the Root Certificate, and of Audit-processing. Towards the upper-left, the statement authentication Not enabled appears. This refers to the possibility of performing LDAP-Based Authentication. If some users are to be authenticated by means of a network-available server, accessed by means of LDAP, left click on the interactive enable tab. The display now appears as follows.
To add a user, left-click on the + Add User control, at the right. The + Add User dialog now appears:

The Authentication Source panel features two checkboxes: one specifying LDAP, the other Couchbase. By default, LDAP is checked: this means that no user-password need be specified on the current dialog. To define a user locally, check the Couchbase checkbox. The dialog now appears as follows:
A password-field has been added, allowing definition of a local user.

Add appropriate entries into the Username and Password fields. The Full Name field may be left blank. Next, consider the Role(s) panel. This displays a list of roles, selectable by means of checkboxes. Note that checkboxes are arranged in a hierarchy. Those initially visible provide the broadest roles (for example, Admin, which provides read-write access on all Couchbase Server administrative features; and Read Only Admin, which provides read-only access to those features). Other checkboxes exist a lower levels, and are accessed by left-clicking on right-pointing arrowheads: when you click, the menu expands, and more arrowheads or checkboxes become visible.
For example, left-click on the Admin checkbox. The Roles panel now appears as follows:

As the illustration shows, selecting the Admin role caused all other high-level roles also to become checked: Read Only Admin, Cluster Admin, and Replication Admin. This is because Admin stands at the top of the hierarchy, and is a superset of all other roles.
To demonstrate this further, left-click on the arrowhead adjacent to bucket Roles, and then, when they become visible, on Bucket Admin and Bucket Full Access. The Role(s) pane now appears as follows:

All roles contained under Bucket Admin and Bucket Full Access, permitting read-write access to administrative and production bucket-data respectively, are checked; since they fall, hierarchically, under Admin.
Now, uncheck Admin, and check Read Only Admin. The Role(s) pane now appears as follows:

This demonstrates that the Bucket Admin and Bucket Full Access roles do not fall under Read Only Admin; and so do not become available when Read Only Admin is checked. This is because both Bucket Admin and Bucket Full Access require write as well as read permission.

When you have finished allocating roles, left-click on Save. The Security view now appears as follows:
The new user is now represented in the main panel, with the allocated roles listed in the Roles column. Note that by left-clicking within the row, you display options for editing:

By left-clicking on Delete, you delete the user. By left-clicking on Edit, you return to the Manage User > testUser dialog, with the options to redefine username, full name, and roles. The Reset Password button only appears when the selected user is locally defined, rather than through LDAP. Left-clicking on the button brings up a dialog that allows redefinition of the user's password:
Note also that by left-clicking on a role, displayed in the Role column, you display a tool-tip, which provides information on the role's signifiance:
For a complete account of the roles you can allocate and their significance, see Roles Used in Access Control.
